block.p: International A3-10 PRISON FOR 2 GERMAN SKINHEADS Two German skinheads who attacked a group of American athletes in October were sentenced to prison, one for two years and eight months and the other for one year. A3

International A3-10 PRISON FOR 2 GERMAN SKINHEADS Two German skinheads who attacked a group of American athletes in October were sentenced to prison, one for two years and eight months and the other for one year. A3

DE KLERK COURTS ZULU KING F. W. de Klerk tried to win the support of the King of the Zulus, Goodwill Zwelethini, for South Africa's universal elections in April. A3 YELTSIN TRIES TO KEEP A TOP AIDE President Yeltsin accepted the resignation of Yegor T. Gaidar, the architect of Russia's economic reforms, and negotiated to retain the Finance Minister, Boris G. Fyodorov. A6 ISRAEL HOPEFUL, WARY ON SYRIA Israel said it saw greater promise of peace with Syria, but expressed extreme caution about the Syrian President's statement that he was ready for normal relations. A8 MEXICO ENVOY HEARS FROM REBELS A special Mexican envoy said the Government had received its first formal contact from rebels in the peasant uprising in the south. A10 SAUDI DEAL IS NEAR ON PAYMENTS Saudi Arabia is nearing agreement with five of the biggest American military contractors to stretch out $10 billion in payments that are due over the next two years. A8 DISCORD AT MEETING ON HAITI The Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide ended a gathering of Haitian politicians with a call to unite against the military in Haiti, but the gathering exposed basic differences among those who back his presidency. A10 ARGENTINA TO JOIN ATOM TREATY Argentina plans to end four decades of defiant policies by joining Latin America's agreement against the spread of nuclear arms. A10 WAR-CRIMES EFFORT CALLED SLOW The United States delegate to the United Nations has accused unspecified countries of not cooperating with efforts to prosecute war criminals in the former Yugoslavia. A10 John Major denied any role in the export of weapons to Iraq. A6 Paris Journal: Pamela Harriman brings some cachet to her job. A4 National A14-21, B10 BIG QUAKE HITS LOS ANGELES A strong predawn earthquake near Los Angeles snapped highway overpasses, leveled buildings, ignited scores of fires, cut off electricity and water to millions, killed at least 30 people and injured hundreds. A1 APARTMENT HOUSE COLLAPSE In the apartment building where the loss of life in the earthquake was greatest, shaken residents remembered waking up to find themselves airborne, falling into the floors below. At least 15 people were killed when the building fell. A1 TRANSPORTATION NIGHTMARE In the metropolitan area that most depends on the car and the truck to carry on its life, the destruction of primary superhighways is a colossal blow, and one that will be felt for months. A1 FINDING A NEW WAY OF LIFE The streets were ghostly, the litter and clutter of destruction everywhere, but slowly in tentative and sometimes unexpected ways the people of the Los Angeles area began to reinvent ways to carry out the business of living in their rattled city. A1 The highway renovation program helped, engineers said. A18 Devastation in a neighborhood close to the earthquake's epicenter. A19 The geology of how the earthquake occurred and why. A20 Electricity, gas, telephones and water services suffered. A20 Federal disaster teams went to the area immediately. A21 SWARTHMORE CAMPUS ABUZZ It was not the paralyzing snow storm that was the talk of the campus as students returned to Swarthmore. Rather it was the case of the student accused of sexual harassment and intimidation. A14 Two old cases involving race are back in Mississippi courts. A14 At a King observance, the President promoted his programs. B10 The Clinton real estate matter is going to a grand jury.
